text: this is the heart of the old city of
Damascus and wherever you look at the
moment there are images of President
Bashar al-assad now his face is very
common here and there are always lots of
portraits of the president but at the
moment
there are thousands literally and that's
because of the election now there are a
couple of ways of looking at this
election there's the view you get from
the opposition and from Western
countries and from general critics of
what the regime here does and that is
that it's a sham that it's a bad joke
the question asked is how can you hope
to have a fair election in a country
that's having a civil war how can you
have an election in a country democratic
election in a country that doesn't have
any democratic institutions now there's
a defense against all those arguments
which you hear in Damascus and it is
that this election is a beginning for
first time since the 50s there are three
phases on the ballot paper and not just
one because previous presidential boats
have been referendums they haven't been
contests that is the argument of course
the official the official who said that
to me said look we all know who's going
to win there is a greater mood of
confidence I'd say in the regime than
there was six or nine months ago and of
course the asset cult of personality
continues to grow a pace look at this
stall here in the market you can get as
had badges you can get these this is the
Hezbollah logo the Lebanese Shia militia
which is because intervention the war
has been absolutely crucial
you get pendants you can get bracelets
the regime here thinks it's on the way
to winning the war and it's giving off
much more confidence than it used to as
a result of that feeling that it has
you
